content:
This article offers steps to build a blog.(Assume the hugo has been installed properly in your PC.)
Hugo install
Clone the theme from the github repository
hugo new site your-site-name ## build your sitecd your-site-name/themes ## change the direction to your-site-name/themesgit clone https://github.com/author/theme-name.git ## replace the "author" and "theme-name"cd .. ## change the direction to your-site-namecp -r /themes/theme-name/exampleSite/* ## copy the files in /themes/theme-name/exampleSite/ to your site folder(your-site-name)Note** There are two config files ( config.toml and hugo.yaml ) in your site floder. You need to copy the items in hugo.yaml to config.toml , and delete the hugo.yaml. You can change the type of config file, either config.toml or config.yaml is ok. I preferconfig.yaml . Build the blog hugo server -D ## in your-site-name folder, run the code, you can see the website in localThere are some errors like.
1.empty website: ensure the exampleSite has been copyed to your-site-name folder and config.toml has been modified.
2. "render of "taxonomy" failed: execute of template failed" : upgrade the version of Hugo.For windows: your can download the latest version of Hugo, and replace the previos .exe file.Push the Public folder to your Github repositoryFor more information to build the your repository in the github, you may refer to the link.
cd pubilc ## run the previous code, the public folder will be generated.git initgit add .git commit "First commit"git remote add origin https://github.com/your-user-name/your-user-name.github.io.git## connect the local site with your github repositorygit push -u origin main ## -u or -f choose one git push -f origin main ## will replace the original version
title: Hugo+Github

Mathematical notation in a Hugo project can be enabled by using third party JavaScript libraries.
In this example we will be using KaTeX
Create a partial under /layouts/partials/math.html Within this partial reference the Auto-render Extension or host these scripts locally. Include the partial in your templates like so: 1 2 3 {{ if or .Params.math .Site.Params.math }} {{ partial "math.html" . }} {{ end }} To enable KaTeX globally set the parameter math to true in a project’s configuration To enable KaTeX on a per page basis include the parameter math: true in content files Note: Use the online reference of Supported TeX Functions
ExamplesInline math: $\varphi = \dfrac{1+\sqrt5}{2}= 1.6180339887â€¦$
$$\varphi = 1+\frac{1} {1+\frac{1} {1+\frac{1} {1+\cdots} } } $$
title: Math Typesetting

Emoji can be enabled in a Hugo project in a number of ways.
The emojify function can be called directly in templates or Inline Shortcodes.
To enable emoji globally, set enableEmoji to true in your site’s configuration and then you can type emoji shorthand codes directly in content files; e.g.
ğŸ™ˆ :see_no_evil: ğŸ™‰ :hear_no_evil: ğŸ™Š :speak_no_evil:
The Emoji cheat sheet is a useful reference for emoji shorthand codes.
N.B. The above steps enable Unicode Standard emoji characters and sequences in Hugo, however the rendering of these glyphs depends on the browser and the platform. To style the emoji you can either use a third party emoji font or a font stack; e.g.
1 2 3 .emoji { font-family: Apple Color Emoji, Segoe UI Emoji, NotoColorEmoji, Segoe UI Symbol, Android Emoji, EmojiSymbols; }
